DataElement.preferredName: Specimen Slide Ductal Breast Carcinoma in Situ Examined Count
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the number or quantity of slide specimens, a bit of tissue mounted on a rectangular piece of glass for microscopic study, examinded to determine the presence of ductal breast carcinoma in situ, a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Specimen Slide Ductal Breast Carcinoma in Situ Examined
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the examination of slide specimens, a bit of tissue mounted on a rectangular piece of glass for microscopic study. for ductal breast carcinoma in situ, a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.:A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Concepts.definition: A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Property.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Examined
Property.preferredDefinition: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, DCIS is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS. --2002:Examined; having been subjected to an examination.

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.
Having been subjected to inspection or evaluation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The number or amount of specimens.
